thread.title: Storm Doris winds reach 94mph in Wales - BBC News
thread.title_full: Storm Doris winds reach 94mph in Wales - BBC News

title: Storm Doris winds reach 94mph in Wales - BBC News
text:
Storm Doris winds reach 94mph in Wales 23 February 2017 Close share panel Media caption Thursday's weather forecast with BBC Wales' Behnaz Akhgar Yellow and amber warnings of strong winds remain in place across Wales as Storm Doris sweeps across the UK. 
The Met Office has issued the warnings covering the whole of Wales until 20:00 GMT on Thursday. 
Gusts of 94mph have been recorded at Capel Curig in Snowdonia and 75mph at Mumbles, Swansea. 
Travel and transport has been disrupted with trains and flights affected as well as roads hit by fallen trees and isolated flooding. 
There have also been reports of power cuts at Anglesey. 
A Scottish Power spokesman said: "We're starting to see some faults in small pockets of Gwynedd and north Wales." 
The Met Office said: "There is still some uncertainty about the track of storm Doris, but increasing confidence that there will be widespread disruption across parts of England and Wales." 
The amber "be prepared" warning covers Ceredigion, Conwy, Denbighshire, Flintshire, Gwynedd, Anglesey, Powys and Wrexham. In Gwynedd, the A5 is closed to the east of Bangor near Penrhyn Castle as a large tree is blocking the road In Aberystwyth, the A44 has been closed due to flooding between the A4159 at Lovesgrove roundabout and the A487 Penglais Road Cardiff Airport has reported some flight delays and Arriva Trains Wales said it expected service disruptions The National Trust has closed Chirk Castle due to concerns about falling tree branches A55 Britannia Bridge, Anglesey, has been shut with traffic diverted to Menai Bridge A477 Cleddau Bridge in Pembrokeshire closed to high-sided vehicles Image copyright Kath Martin Image caption Kath Martin's trampoline took off down the street at Tongwynlais, near Cardiff 
While the strongest winds are expected to be short-lived, the Met Office warned of potential damage, danger and disruption, with trees likely to be damaged or blown over. 
The less serious yellow warning, urging people to be aware, covers a wider area. 
Gusts of 50-60mph are expected, with the risk of 70mph on coasts and hills. 
The Met Office said: "Travel services could be affected including some restrictions on bridges and disruption to ferries. Some damage to trees and buildings is also possible." Media caption Storm Doris winds whip up sea at Aberystwyth promenade 
Have you been affected by the weather? Email with your pictures, videos and experiences. 
Please include a contact number if you are willing to speak to a BBC journalist. You can also contact us in the following ways:
